Write a summary about 'astronomy'. Limit the output to 200 words. Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects and phenomena that originate outside the Earth's atmosphere. It involves physics, mathematics, and chemistry, and is concerned with the origin, evolution, and fate of objects in the universe. Key areas of astronomy include the study of the Sun, stars, galaxies, and the large-scale structure of the universe. Modern astronomy uses a variety of observational techniques, including telescopes, spectroscopes, and space-based observatories, to gather data about the universe. It also involves theoretical work to understand the data and develop models of astronomical phenomena. Astronomy has played a significant role in the development of scientific thought, including the Copernican Revolution and the discovery of the expanding universe. It continues to be an active field of research, with many unanswered questions about the nature of the universe and its ultimate fate.

Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects (such as stars, galaxies, planets, and others) and phenomena that originate outside Earth's atmosphere. It involves physics, mathematics, and chemistry, and employs observational techniques and data analysis to explain the origins and evolution of objects and events in the universe. Key areas of astronomy include solar astronomy (studying the Sun and other stars), planetary science (examining the planets, their moons, and other bodies in our solar system), and astrophysics (investigating the physical properties and behaviors of celestial objects and phenomena). Astronomy plays a significant role in understanding the cosmos and its history, from the formation of the universe to the exploration of exoplanets and the search for extraterrestrial life.

It involves physics, mathematics, and chemistry to explain the origin, evolution, and physical properties of objects like stars, galaxies, and planets. Key branches include astrophysics, cosmology, and astrobiology. Astronomy began in ancient civilizations, with notable contributions from ancient Greeks like Aristarchus and Ptolemy. Major advances came with the invention of the telescope in the 17th century, leading to discoveries like the phases of Venus and the moons of Jupiter. Today, astronomy uses advanced technology like space telescopes and radiotelescopes to study the universe, from our solar system to the most distant galaxies.

It involves physics, mathematics, and chemistry, and is divided into several subfields, including astrophysics, cosmology, and planetary science. Astronomy aims to understand the universe's origins, evolution, and ultimate fate, as well as the properties and behavior of celestial bodies. It uses observations, theoretical models, and computational methods to explore phenomena like stars, galaxies, black holes, and the cosmic microwave background radiation. Astronomy has significantly contributed to our understanding of the universe, from the discovery of exoplanets to the confirmation of the Big Bang theory.
